Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

The proposed object of study is the Schlick Zirkel, a group of philosophically-oriented scientists in 1920s Vienna that eventually evolved into the Vienna Circle, which is of great importance and has received much attention in the history of the philosophy of science. The intellectual contribution is both a close study of the ideas, insights, and intellectual innovations of the Zirkel concerning the foundations of science and of theoretical reasoning, and a historical study of its members. The project will serve to clarify of how specialists, professional philosophers and scientific practitioners, develop an understanding of the scientific enterprise. It will also help to explain how distinct individuals, with different backgrounds and training, and belonging to distinct disciplines, arrive at their own conception of the scientific enterprise. This process, which ultimately shapes and forms the popular perception of science, involves careful examination, extended discussions, and heated debates before a consensus emerges

Technical Summary

The intrinsic merit of the proposed work derives from the significance of the Zirkel in the development of Twentieth Century philosophical thought and the fact that the Zirkel has received little critical attention in the literature. The Zirkel was the original group which evolved into the Vienna Circle, a major source of Logical Empiricism, which dominated philosophical thought about science throughout most of the Twentieth Century. The last two decades have seen a resurgence of scholarly interest in the Vienna Circle and in the early development of Logical Empiricism. During this period, the influence of Kantian thought on Logical Empiricism has been emphasized, while the contribution of the Zirkel has been largely neglected. The proposed project will remedy both the lack of scholarly interest in a leading influence on recent philosophy of science while correcting the mistaken impressions which have resulted from this neglect.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the present period of the project's duration, focus was directed on the activities of the Schlick Zirkel membbers during, and immediately after their study of Bertrand Russell's and Alfred North Whitehead's Principia Mathematica and Ludwig Wittgenstein's Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus. Of principal interesst in this regard were the reactions of Moritz Schlick, in his 1926 essay, "Experience, Cognition, and Metaphysics," in which he first began to forge the identity of linguistic and epistemological structure and use it as a basis for determining a criterion of cognitive significance. The original insights of this essay were elaborated and further articulated in a series of essays written from 1926 through his 1932 London lectures on "Form and Content". The 'form and content' phllosophy was never very successful and, finally, it was refuted in 1934 by Rudolf Carnap. So even though it was ultimately unsuccessful, Schlick's thinking during this period indicates the direction of his thought before he discovered his key insight that the legitimacy of linguistic structures must be grounded in grammatical rules. This conclusion provides new insight into the relations of developing Logical Empiricism and science, while clarifying aspects of what makes modern science distinctive. It also sets the stage for the conclusion, that it is the conceptionof language in terms of grammar that finally captured the Logical Empiricists' mature conceptioni.
